title: Not so super life insurance has way to go
text:
Exposing super fund members to poor policies and poor insurers with poor processes is simply not good enough.

It says something about the complexity of life insurance that the industry couldn’t even agree with the regulator about the basic statistics on the sector’s performance.

On Thursday, a rather thundering report from the Australian Securities and Investment Commission showed that for the total and permanent disability (TPD) claims it examined during 2016-17, only 65 per cent of claims were accepted by insurers, with the balance either declined or withdrawn by the consumer.

The Financial Services Council, which represents the life insurance sector, hit back almost immediately, declaring the numbers were badly out of date and failed to capture the big improvements in industry practice.

But there was a problem with the FSC numbers from the 2018 financial year. While they showed that 88 per cent of claims were approved, the data excluded withdrawn claims – a key problem, given the level of withdrawn claims is an issue that ASIC feels deserves closer inspection as it may suggest consumers are abandoning faulty claims processes.

The lobby group argues withdrawn claim numbers are falling too, but can’t quantify this as it doesn’t have the data. Nonetheless, the FSC argues that even if you assume withdrawn claims have been steady, there has still been an appreciable increase in overall payment rates.

ASIC’s response? Things might be getting better, but there’s still a heck of a lot of work to do.
description: Insurers and superannuation trustees need to work hard to ensure total and permanent disability cover is actually delivering.
